WcsM_tv9CTWxICurjPJO3A.text: Amazing ramen but you will end up waiting a long time if you arrive at peak hours. Service is also great and friendly and I would agree with other comments that probably best ramen in London . We are now regulars here and have learned when to be there to avoid the queue

q1oTiM10zy3Jfvx_ty04vA.text: Kanadaya does the best ramen in the UK! Try avoid 1-2pm or 7-8.30pm slot as you will most likely be queuing for their seats. Early lunch like 12.30pm or early dinner at around 6.30pm are always good time slots with no queues. Even though their speciality is added truffle oil, I find the truffle oil smell a bit too thick and strong in noodle soup or with the edamame beans. My favourite dish is their Tonkatsu x with 'hard' noodles (yes, you can customise your noodle!). No matter how many times I dine at Kanadaya, I can't get enough of their noodles and I will always be back!

UmY6Q-NBeFe71qGOGS7JSw.text: The Ramen here is simply amazing, the best I've had. I tried both the spicy options at different times, and they both have a good level of spice, while maintaining great flavor.

z0ZfNaboV6Ot2heg1Sml8Q.text: Hi. We really liked this little place. There was a fast seating line - true to ramen houses.  We all had different ramens and I loved my chashu ramen. We also got a side dish of chashudon and the rice under the meat was so good.  I think everyone wants to go back.  So far we've tried a dumpling house, fast Japanese food and Indian in London and surprisingly it was not good.  So glad we found this little chain

Y3McA9KZ8SjKTQLLeIQecA.text: The broth is kinda light, and mixed with noodle's smell. Go there 5 minutes before they open and avoid lining up.Unfortunately, I can't finish their ramen because the strange taste of the broth.

esTZt6sd8ywXDS0r00dMCw.text: The ramen is still delicious but the wait staff is terrible! We were the second pair of customers seated right as the restaurant opened for lunch service. izzdqhM4yDSbdiYgzG5ThQ.text: We got to this place on a Sunday afternoon and there was a line. Given that this place seats about 25-30 people, be prepared to wait. We were seated after about 35 minutes, but the wait was definitely worth it. Their ramen was superb. The broth was creamy, the noodles firm and the ingredients were fresh. Highly recommended!

hhH6470syGq2d3BAJdEf9g.text: After a horrible experience at Bone Daddies, I wanted some "do over" ramen.  While not perfect, Kanada-ya came through with the goods.  I'd give them 3.5 stars if Yelp allowed.  The tonkotsu broth is definitely closer to what one might find in Japan versus that stuff Bone Daddies serves.  All in all, good but not great.  We'll see what happens when Ippudo opens across the street.

NS-Z6najrnDSDWFab1pAWQ.text: Excellent excellent ramen. Tiny place so expect to wait.... But worth it. The owner is very kind and service is superb. Will definitely comeback. I had the original ramen and my wife charsiu delicious.

OTQr7P_1fNid2USDLtNmbw.text: the best ramen place in london! the original ramen was awesome! add eggs and everything is perfect  definitely have to add eggs cause' its just too good it melts in your mouth. you can choose the noodles ( regular, soft/hard) depending on what you prefer, i asked for regular lol. it tasted very nice. the pork was  and the best part is the pork broth.. OMG.. i can drink the broth like theres no tomorrow haha. definitely should try this ramen when you come near holbornthe second time i came here i tried gekikara ramen (which is on their extra menu) i prefer the original one since i cant take spicy because they put a lot of chili ( i think) until the broth became red. but the good part is that they add shredded pork which is very sweet and tender i love it! overall i'll give 5/5

VHQbpTc3VI2HcqjJa11NJg.text: One of the best ramen in London, has lots of char siu topping and fills you up! Definitely add the half boiled egg too. But avoid peak time because you can't book and you have to queue outside

xMxSyx_nMy4Dwv5CU31nOQ.text: One of the best ramen we've had in London! Simple menu, super tasty. Great environment and really friendly staff!

vkn0elMGf8mVFcvoytIN2Q.text: I've eaten at bone daddies, shoryu, tonkatsu and ippudo. Bone daddies, meh too watery. Shoryu noodles are low quality. Ippudo is safe but not knock your socks off good. I also grew up on the stuff in Hawaii. This is the best there is in London. Not leaps and bounds better than Ippudo, but good enough that it's worth crossing the street. That being said, if it's a massive wait or you are not in the area, Ippudo is a good alternative!

OdHtOvQ6diaUUu-kXkdi4w.text: Firstly I would like to say it's the best ramen I have had in London. It's still not as good as when I had in Tokyo. But what would be. This is as authentic and flavoursome as you are going to get. The Hanjuku egg is a must. I had the Pork Chashu with firm noodles. It's a very small place so be warned that you might have to queue but it's worth it on a cold day for sure.

J5VNMGGFePLQliQHwCih_g.text: Simple, good, satisfying ramen. The broth is amazing. There might be a small queue, but you are seated, served and provided with a big bowel of ramen quickly.

ATliJfbOjgEe7aXUQelU_g.text: This place serves up by far the best ramen in London. It may be small and queues form as soon as it opens but it's worth a visit. The broth is packed with so much flavour and the noodles are cooked to preference. There may only be a few variations to pick off the menu, but all come with generous top quality ingredients. I ended up going for and would highly recommend the spicy ramen which didn't overpower the broth and topped it off with an extra egg which was still lovely and runny. (Visit - 18/05/2015 Lunch)

hw141rInj2H6bQ86HAaGUg.text: People are talking about this restaurant and I can see a long queue waiting outside so I could not wait to try their Ramen. The menu is quite simple with only 3 items priced 10, 11 and 13. I order original tonkotsu ramen cost £10 without service charge which is a good price for a bowl of Ramen. However the bowl is so small and I literally can count 3 small pieces of pork. The soup is nice but I did not get it much as well as their noodle in such a small bowl. I complaint about this and the waiter said that's how everyone get it in here !!! To compare with other Ramen restaurant in soho, i do not think I will come back here as I will have better choices not too far away. And there is a new big Ramen restaurant coming soon just opposite this restaurant so I am waiting to see how long the queue will last.

bchBIEq56RwIK3a0ChfGNQ.text: Delicious ramen. Very genuine and tasty and filling. Doesn't take reservations so allow time for that! Three types of pork ramen available. Would return.

-TTltZR74wa_M-W5f3K10w.text: O Kanada [ya]!Our home of porky broth! True chashu nestled amidst thine porky froth. With glowing hearts we savour thee, The True noodles hard - or soft! From far and wide,O Kanada [ya], we stand in line for thee. God,  thine ramen's garlicky glory!O Kanada [ya], we stand in line for thee.O Kanada [ya], we stand in line for thee.Yeah.Where to start...Kanada-Ya is one of the newest ramen additions to London.  It's awesome.  Even though I've had to wait an hour for my ramen on one occasion, it's still awesome (beware, there are queues at lunchtime too).Kanada-Ya is the David to Ippudo's Goliath bearing down on it from across the street in the premises formerly containing Damson Cafe.  There's not a lot of seating (maybe room for 25-30 people at a time?) and is perpetually steamy, thanks to the small soup area (to call it an exposition kitchen would be generous, it's pretty dinky).Anyhow.  Kanada-Ya does very few things - tonkotsu ramen and onigiri (and ramune, for those of you into that sort of thing) - but it does them extremely well.  My standard order there is the chashu men (tonkotsu with the bowl rim lined with pork, fungus, and nori) with extra black garlic oil (highly recommended for all orders) and a hanjuku egg - it's a shame the egg doesn't come as standard, but never mind.  Also, you get to choose your noodle hardness (I go for extra hard just like my...abs) which is tripleplusgood: the noodles here are the thin Hakata-type - whilst I generally prefer thicker noodles, getting to choose noodle hardness really puts Kanada-ya up in my estimation.  The broth is delicious - I've been mulling it over, but I think the broth flavour just about pips Bone Daddies (there, I said it).  Simply put, one of the best bowls of ramen I've had - whilst I haven't been to Ippudo in London, I have been to a branch in Kuala Lumpur and Kanada-ya's is far superior.Yes, the service is pretty haphazard.  But for me the ramen erases any bad feeling I may have about the place; besides, it's not like the staff are rude - it's more a case of inefficiency and hopefully will improve over time.We're really spoiled for ramen in London.  Really spoiled.  It's an awesome time to be here.

r2otNamHNh3YVcd2283cZA.text: The first time I came here, there was a queue so I left. I came here for the second time and thank God there was no queue. But the place was still pretty packed and I was seated at the last available spot at a communal table. The service was very attentive and my food came fairly quickly. I ordered the Chashu Men and it was quite delicious. The broth is flavorful as expected, but I do find the frothiness a bit strange... I expected the chashu collar to be a bit more marbled and felt that it was bit too sweet for my taste. Maybe I should have opted for the pork belly instead. The noodles were good. And the sous vide eggs... ARE TO DIE FOR. It's perfection in that aspect compared to Bone Daddies and Shoryu in my opinion. Great place!

hkPogz0g97zzccEFTcq7gA.text: Moyasi Ramen with very rich broth (very fatty) was disappointing in this new restaurant.  There was very little meat -  three pieces of cold pork with lots of fat - and the stock was nothing special and bland. The Chashu Men's meat was better with soft hot pork.  This is a new restaurant so they have plenty of time to adjust the menu and flavour.  It is way too overpriced and not a good value for money.  I definitely had far better one in Japan.
